title: I preferred it when Sherlock and Watson were just solving fairly believable mysteries
text:
TV Opinion I preferred it when Sherlock and Watson were just solving fairly believable mysteries If the BBC really is serious about going up against the big boys of Netflix and Amazon Prime Taboo is exactly the kind of thing it should be making. Share Mark Gatiss as Mycroft Holmes (Photo: BBC) Share Get celebs   Thank you for subscribing!   
Whatever Mark Gatiss did in last night’s Sherlock finale he was never going to top his eye-catching, three-minute cameo as a bloated, foul-mouthed George IV the previous evening. 
Likewise, Sherlock itself was never going to shake my belief that its BBC1 unstablemate Taboo, in which Tom Hardy stars as a brooding, grunting, vengeful 19th century shipping company boss/suspected crazy cannibal, is TV’s best drama right now. 
Sherlock will still grab all the headlines and the fangirling on social media, but surely I can’t be the only viewer who preferred it when Holmes and Watson were just solving fairly believable mysteries. If it went back to that I’d welcome another series or two with open arms. 
However, if the BBC decided to spend its drama budget on something else instead, dipping back into the Taboo end of the market would be a good start. Tom Hardy as James Delaney in Taboo (Photo: BBC) 
If the BBC really is serious about going up against the big boys of Netflix and Amazon Prime this is exactly the kind of thing it should be making. 
It’s one of those gritty, slow-burning period pieces where the cast are on top form and where viewers sighing, “I have no clue what’s going on” should be seen as a compliment rather than a criticism. 
There’s such an air of menace and unpredictability running through it that I swear I only breathed twice during Saturday’s episode. 
What gave me the coldest chill though were the constant reminders that Britain was once at war with America. 
Which reminds me... 
I hope y’all enjoy Donald Trump’s inauguration on Friday. Like us on Facebook
